column5:
The journey continues. The plot thickens. I have a nice overview article  of Imagining After Capitalism that has just come out in the Association of Professional Futurists Compass Magazine.
https://t.co/pL1iQMj3mb https://t.co/cZ0ABzSmBo

Very thoughtful piece on post-scarcity (abundance). Aaron Benanav suggests the automation or technological ical path under-estimates de-industrialization and stagnation and the social and political factors involved
https://t.co/jyShXVDmO7

Super-intelligence explores paths beyond human intelligence. Nick Bostrom notes the importance of shaping initial condition and making strategic choices now.  It could be an enabler of abundance, but it comes with risk. https://t.co/mgLekQkNEe https://t.co/vbiXGCut8T

The longer that we delay acting, the more possible that "crazy" schemes become. 
https://t.co/d4RcNm4LXa

Sometimes the most useful tools are the simplest. I sometimes do a “start, stop, continue” activity for next steps. We list new activities to start, old ones to stop, and some to simply continue. But why am I thinking about it in a post on accountability?
https://t.co/dJCea4jE6m https://t.co/LBRCXM5lpl
@WensupuYang ooo, I like that too, ha ha. It's really Pierre Wack. BTW, I loved Tom Chermack's book on Pierre Foundations of Scenario Planning!
@BaldrigeProgram That was fun for me, too! Keep up the good work!

If you decided to take the plunge and come to UH for foresight education, what do you get? Or perhaps more fundamentally, what are the basics of foresight education? I like UMI: understanding, mapping, and influencing the future. https://t.co/K9yhInfzG4 https://t.co/VyuVYHvITv

Utopia ... No Thanks. The “long twentieth century” beginning in 1870 was an era of unprecedented growth. It is not the norm. Alternatives to growth are not as crazy at they might seem. And he doesn’t seem to be much of a fan of utopia.  https://t.co/sdBObPUmdC https://t.co/rk5eAfbgQ6

The Steady-State economy idea, popularized by Herman Daly, is an economy characterized by stable size. It is flanked on the one side by more growth – same pace or slow it down. On the other side, degrowth says we need to take active steps to reverse growth. Where do you net out? https://t.co/iY4oJE8C69
@riveong ha, I haven't put it in Diigo yet. Please do! I appreciate you keeping your eyes peeled.

An important point raised here about differences in the growth circumstances of Global North and Global South. A degrowth approach needs to be appropriate to particular situations.  
An open letter to the ‘post-growth’ movement by Samantha Suppiah https://t.co/LOzAxWrj89

Oof. Poverty has increased for the first time in 25 years. The very richest have become dramatically richer and corporate profits have hit record highs, driving an explosion of inequality. Survival of the Richest via @Oxfam https://t.co/Ui7GQkdbQ9

To work or not to work. That is the question ...  may I offer “post-work” as the answer?
https://t.co/yhjrcXEWv3 https://t.co/Fvu34pJSf8

I like to keep it light and have fun, but this was not from pro futurists (field didn't even exist then). > How Futurists Envisioned the Future in the 1920s: Moving Walkways, Personal Helicopters, Glass-Domed Cities, Dream Recorders & More https://t.co/Wcw9LJGZxS via @openculture
Mapping the future(s) https://t.co/DQObpggl0f via @nextwavefutures
@garrygolden ha ha, I've wondered the same, and am thinking about building a collection. Nostalgia, archive, I'm not sure. Lemme know before you toss!

We had a "Green Leapfrog" scenario for China about 15 years ago. Client didn't believe it ... but here we are. >How 4 Chinese enterprises are taking action on sustainable development  https://t.co/AYGpCCejqG via @social_handles.twitter
@quoll21 well, I guess that settles that :-)

Eisenstein’s work on a sacred (or gift) economy is a great add to After Capitalism. He suggests shrinking the formal economy... and includes the adoption of negative interest to discourage rentier approaches. See https://t.co/gIRBgM1X5G
https://t.co/slvAjFtnjV

This article points out challenges for Degrowth. In particular, hard to say the Global South shouldn't grow!
https://t.co/eLBT77tCfh

Two nice treatments of post-capitalist futures: Mason’s 2015 Post-Capitalism and Srnicek & Williams 2016 Inventing the Future. They make the case for the decline of Neoliberal Capitalism, the need to design a transition, and to create a vision of an abundance future.

Longtermism and the futures ecosystem. There are useful ideas in this philosophy for futurists to consider. This book would have benefited from reviewing and drawing upon the work of futurists, but it totally ignores our work. Hmm. https://t.co/b8m4G2EX7z
Restoring American Capitalism | City Journal https://t.co/DgIsFyL4AN

Understanding, Mapping, and Influencing the Future:
What do we teach about the future? What does one need to know to be an effective futurist? https://t.co/CGHoqcp3ij https://t.co/GeARyMKhNX
Random thought. Gel shaving cream is the worst. Which made me think, what is the greenest way to shave, or should we all have long shaggy beards?

We produce an enormous amount of material goods that are unnecessary, destructive, inefficient, designed for a throw-away society - if U want love or community ... buy a Dr. Pepper? https://t.co/ysX1ErNKtv via @truthout

@HowardRock8 Yikes. My initial tweet was early into my exploration of longtermis. I was not aware of the questions about Torres's work (nor had I seen it before). I have since read MacAskill's work, and in general it seems Torres's tweets fairly represented his work.

Degrowth in Fortune ... the inching toward the mainstream continues>
It’s time to quit capitalism’s obsession with growth. Focus on ‘degrowth’ instead, some economists say https://t.co/7ukRmrv8ZQ

Happy to share about our new University of Houston Foresight Advisory Board and our planning activity. 
https://t.co/rmMwJe0Wc9 https://t.co/ORUECgHWCO

Post-work is not a new idea. from the 1880s: rather than overproducing commodities that capitalism then exports abroad, workers should enjoy their abundance at home and only work three hours a day, letting machines do most of the work.
https://t.co/O50rAzaPLd
Wow! Really big thinkers collaborating on this piece. Pay attention! > Degrowth can work — here’s how science can help https://t.co/ZEpPQgaUBf
Lessons from the Red Tsar -- trying to understand is how a civilized society can effectively go mad and allow unbelievably horrible things to happen https://t.co/MnfqKJfZKP
Unfortunately this happens too often with new developments; I remember dealing with this re: organic and natural foods in the 1990s
Oooooo... Wonderful, lovely, and exciting thinking > The Case for Universal Creative Income, by @ljin18 https://t.co/eaUcKKAHz0

Interesting "accomplishment" Capitalism's stunning advancements... most advanced tech companies in  world,Amazon, Apple, Microsoft. Goal is to produce tech companies? [poverty reduction noted,tbf]
25 Most Capitalist Nations in the World https://t.co/EDEfFeRLmE via @YahooFinance

Terrible. After Capitalism would enable people to create without having to worry about making a living. 
New book argues that “chokepoint capitalists” discourage creativity —all while making investors and executives rich, writes @amlowenstein: https://t.co/EZXW323ZM9
Enjoyed chatting with Australian futurist Peter Hayward on the popular FuturePod series about After Capitalism. https://t.co/BDRD0cppO6 https://t.co/ylvhfFjLfv

Post-Growth is a concept put forward by Tim Jackson that emphasizes strengthening ecologically and socially sustainable practices given the physical limits of the earth. He shares the latest version of his thinking in a recent book: https://t.co/qlTy5jhxWe
Torres has an excellent collection of posts on longermism

Introducing people to the formal study of the future is  key to what we do at University of Houston Foresight. We know that our students "stumble upon" foresight one day and realize "that's it!" So we need to be out there as much as we can. https://t.co/LJLCfhnvyE https://t.co/cLje7Uyed4
Nice graphic of foresight in government from our foresight friends in Finland!

The assumption here is that economies need a growth model. I suppose degrowth can be a type of model? Beyond varieties of capitalism: a growth model approach - UK in a changing Europe https://t.co/IDlnPBMii0

So now post-capitalism is showing up in style magazines? It's inching toward Horizon Two! 
> Living in a Post-Capitalist Society: What Does it Mean for Us? | Hudson Valley Style Magazine https://t.co/4MPBWf6HAF via @HudsonValleySTl

DiLorenzo’s Politically Incorrect Guide to Economics finds some younger conservatives as critics of capitalism. While the Left attacks capitalism as the primary engine of the West’s success, these right criticize it as the source of the West’s decline.   https://t.co/mVCZZmsqHX

Does After Capitalism emerge organically? This idea has been rattling around in my brain since reading the excellent sci fi novel  Stealing Worlds by futurist and  writer Karl Schroeder. https://t.co/kwNm2620jU https://t.co/y7yIEU1X5e

Nice analysis. Once can only hope the anger fueling tribalism is cooling (not sure I see it, though).
Is America angry enough for Trump? @UnHerd https://t.co/IcCDANZlAo

We have to watch for the "it's your fault" line of argument for capitalism's problems. There is some truth in it, and at first glance looks clever. Key assumption here > consumers set prices. Hmmmm... Have y'all seen the 10 companies that own most consumer product brands graphic?

Most After Capitalism concepts suggest the pathway and governance would be local, decentralized and direct democratic. Overwhelmingly so. But, what if a country with a benevolent authoritarian government in effect “ordered” the switch to After Capitalism? https://t.co/b2hpkNxNQM https://t.co/TCBuAmEF7y

A nice analysis of options on how to address work going forward: worker control or post-work (note: could former evolve into the latter?)
Alec Stubbs: American workers feel alienated, helpless and overwhelmed — here’s one way to alleviate their malaise https://t.co/JPr5zwj7LN

Pluralist Commonwealth (Gar Alperovitz) advocates an evolutionary reconstruction path based on democratization of wealth, community as a guiding theme, decentralization and substantial democratic planning. Very common themes in After Capitalism concepts! https://t.co/hZQe8zVAFD

@nextwavefutures @aloha_futures @PeterScoblic @DrMattFinch @AriW @wendyinfutures @jpolchar @samwashdc @nils_gilman @discomplex @Sohailfutures @MarcusBussey @elinafuturist @laetusx Ha, true. Maybe it's that we old-timers take it for granted that Shell was hugely influential, but it is a bit of a surprise to those newer in the field?
I really like Wolff's stuff, but don't entirely agree with this comment. I think lots of people are in it to build an alternative the current system.

@PeterScoblic @DrMattFinch @AriW @wendyinfutures @jpolchar @samwashdc @aloha_futures @nils_gilman @discomplex okay, I will say favorite rather than best and go with Tom Chermack's wonderful "Foundations of Scenario Planning" that tells the Pierre Wack story.

@aloha_futures @PeterScoblic @DrMattFinch @AriW @wendyinfutures @jpolchar @samwashdc @nils_gilman @discomplex @Sohailfutures @MarcusBussey @nextwavefutures @elinafuturist @laetusx I going to dodge your question for now. Too hard! Interesting tidbit - students picked and reviewed several books on scenarios for Futures Research. It became a running joke re: how many have a Shell connection.

It is important to consider that fascism is not just a "right wing" thing. One of my favorite early books was Friendly Fascism by Bertram Gross. And this article is though-provoking.
https://t.co/PVCT02EmKK

Some of my more experienced colleagues might remember the Stephen Covey "habit" of "Begin with the End in mind." It gets a futurist spin here - Begin with the Future in mind. 
https://t.co/EXXkVpOmIF https://t.co/0IOyWwvRgQ

An excellent overview of the ideas of Delong's Slouching toward Utopia that summarizes the 5 periods of progress and backlashes of capitalism since the 1870s. Terrific context for understanding the need for After Capitalism 
https://t.co/qxagxYrYmv
I have joked how we missed that self-driving vehicles wouldn't use smart roads ... but maybe we just missed what the smart roads were for?

Local is fundamental to After Capitalism. I call it out as a specific concept, using the local living economies concept of BALLE, now https://t.co/OybnF5MhSr. It promotes human-scale, interconnected local living economies and a network of socially responsible businesses and more.
There is still time to be smart about this ... but not heading in the right direction.

Capitalism's search for growth leaves no stone -- or mushroom -- unturned. 
Why Psychedelic Capitalism Sucks https://t.co/SRSejYXC5N

The Singularity is a popular vision – it has its own university! https://t.co/LtQq10urhY that describes a tech-driven route to After Capitalism.Futurist Ray Kurzweil sees a future of exponential tech change eventually leading to no clear distinction between humans and machines.

Umair on the negative side of things, but hard to argue -- is it shifting even faster than we thought? > This Isn’t Late Stage Capitalism Anymore. Now It’s End Stage Capitalism. by @umairh https://t.co/6eVqHKikKm

Is the Great Resignation the start of the Great Opt-Out? Probably not, but there is a long-term signal here. 
https://t.co/f7Gs3FyoF9 https://t.co/jFdSN81LZp
Is this possible? Sure. Is it "After Capitalism?" No, just another iteration. >Are We Living Under ‘Technofeudalism’? https://t.co/pim1dXaJFl via @intelligencer
@richDis48 I really like Scharmer's work overall!
@Cekent awesome, thank you kind sir! Talked to Carbone ... he told me about your new gig at Idea Couture. Good for you!!!!

Excellent analysis of abundance and scarcity! "Reclaiming abundance ... we already have all that we need... inequitable distribution and allocation ... exacerbates our anxiety around scarcity."
Reclaiming Abundance Under Capitalism - YES! Magazine https://t.co/neQqYhgm9l
We talked about running for office on a post capitalist platform ... and here we are.

Otto Scharmer's “Eco” concept advocates a switch from current ego-centric approaches leading toward planetary disaster to eco-centric ones that emphasizes the well-being of the whole. Check out the full story in his book leading from the Emerging Future,   https://t.co/hBH9fZaeml https://t.co/LIHwV5KsAb
John Mackey: ‘Capitalism Is the Greatest Thing Mankind Has Ever Done’ | Dr Rainer Zitelmann https://t.co/VcmKhChXgb via @feeonline

I'm late to the party on this concept, but I like it: 
The Making Of Generation U & Why A New Model Of Retirement Advice Is Needed Now via @forbes https://t.co/f32ZHEtgnS
Visions of Postcapitalist Design: An Incomplete Survey https://t.co/kqsjXwnVVo #Capitalism #Design #Sustainability via @mitpress

"Seeing the Future": I'm sharing a light "pop" article on me and UH Foresight program. (It only took us eight years to get noticed). t is kinda fun to see how journalists/PR folks with no idea of what we do try to make sense of it. https://t.co/uvrO58eZ5t https://t.co/KpiBFgMvsZ
A start re: reintegrating with nature

Great concept, but not sure we are here yet: "beyond capitalism and communism lies an impressive array of other ways to live"
https://t.co/l7ea3hj7OZ

Aaron Bastani's "Fully Automated Luxury Communism" sees a  a shift towards worker-owned production and a state-financed transition to universal services. He see a big role for technology that brings together our Non-Workers Paradise and Tech-Led Abundance. https://t.co/YWBKuAHHkT https://t.co/AMZEhQzOPo
The CIA wants to bring woolly mammoths back from extinction https://t.co/bQZuy7EKgR

The future of values in a podcast; are values hard-wired ... or evolving? what role do they play in the shift to After Capitalism?  And lots of other juicy topics! https://t.co/vzuFmk4VX1 https://t.co/Fqv4tXSo9U

Still seems pretty small to me, but making progress! Chicago's Cook County just launched what they say is the largest guaranteed basic income pilot program in the country, becoming a leader in the national movement toward basic income. https://t.co/cBUfQ4zCuF via @HuffPostPol
Here we see the shift from modern values (competition) to postmodern values (participation) https://t.co/kULOefbS1Y
We can't even use "it's gonna get weird." We're already there. > Cat litter box myths are suddenly a culture war flashpoint. Here's how that happened. https://t.co/3r1nbTj2a3 via @nbcnews

Nice piece lays out a case for working within the system rather than "giving up" on it. A lot of these cases are ahead on the path to After Capitalism.
Patagonia's grand gesture sends the wrong message about ethical capitalism https://t.co/a7sB2InBE0 via @physorg_com
Inequality is one of seven key drivers for After Capitalism!

Beware that alternatives to capitalism will be labeled as socialism or communism to scare people away > The manifesto thus proposes to implement a socialist economy, even if it does not explicitly use that term.
For Anti-Capitalists, “The Future Is Public” https://t.co/i9XaSOo69A

A signal of the move toward the Non-Workers Paradise image. First, workers need to get organized >
The Union Wave: Reviewing a Landmark Year of Organizing the Unorganized https://t.co/RzhfMmDR6L via @Socialist Alternative

A good take on what a Collapse might look like ... and this is trajectory we are on ... thus the shift to After Capitalism 
Professors call for more research into climate-change related threats to civilization https://t.co/YOje4a7y9m via @physorg_com

A very reasonable approach to help with the culture wars … and help clear the path to After Capitalism >
Why Right-Wing Traditionalism Is So Appealing to So Many https://t.co/h4r5BF91Eb via @thedailybeast

Capitalism has a development problem. The problems with capitalism are not the same everywhere. After Capitalism focuses on what many are calling late-stage capitalism. In others words, it’s nearing the end of its life span. But not everywhere. https://t.co/SIU8rPNtln https://t.co/yN4OVhptZT

Interesting. While most of the after capitalism discussion has been in the developed world owing to  the growth challenge, it's not just there >
Era of 'oligarchic capitalism' over in Kazakhstan, vows president https://t.co/hv4oRijWia
Brilliant post by futurist Mina McBride on toothpaste tube economics - reminds me of systems principle: "there is no such thing as a free lunch." https://t.co/OuZvKOTwTP

Brad Delong: The best minds of a generation moving to South of Market in San Francisco to figure out how to scare the shit out of people and glue their eyeballs to screens — that’s not a terribly good use of human brainpower. https://t.co/tsnQNN8LiX via @voxdotcom
Worker coops are a step in the right direction to After Capitalism. California, as it often does (not always) leads the way.
Yep, it's getting weirder....

The After Capitalism journey ... only 5 or 10 years ago, any mention of alternatives to capitalism in public would get an eye roll or a chilly or even hostile reaction. But now ...
https://t.co/lAObRHwBzf

Kate Raworth’s Doughnut has gained some notoriety and inspired a few pilot projects. It advocates a social foundation of well-being that no one falls below and an ecological ceiling of planetary pressure that is not exceeded. Fits w/ Circular Commons. See https://t.co/9LWLCsZAir https://t.co/Ts55JiY16w
Futurists call this a bellwether or indicator of the future; fits Circular Commons > California bans the sale of new gas-powered cars by 2035 https://t.co/ynAE1cyeMS
Decline in traditional values fits with long-term trends [https://t.co/GSDrw0ggap] > America's Christian majority could end by 2070 https://t.co/AB4h9QinoK

Redistribution signal re: Non-Workers Paradise > Spain's coalition govt's downwardly redistributive fiscal reforms include a temporary "solidarity" tax on 23,000 wealthiest residents to ease the cost-of-living crisis on working people.
https://t.co/nCR4XbBsFx via @commondreams

One of the major obstacles to After Capitalism is stalemate. We are going to need to make some challenging decisions. Today we look at how an overzealous search for bias is reinforcing stalemate. https://t.co/MUHTolzhBX

This "bad jobs" phenomenon is core to the Non-Workers Paradise image. The fight for better jobs is a losing battle. Automation can help, but has to be applied strategically. "The great American labor paradox: Plentiful jobs, most of them bad" https://t.co/Qx747jHEKQ via @qz

Degrowth by Kallis et al. has been picking up steam [see https://t.co/1ARYv0ym7l]. It challenges economic as an objective, as we are at a point where a radical approach is needed. Favors grassroots practices such as eco-communities, co-ops, local currencies, barter, commons, etc.

"In a sign of growing political and economic dissatisfaction, American support for both capitalism and socialism are in decline." This is encouraging. An opening for new images of life After Capitalism. https://t.co/HAjHl11Gio via @reason

An indicator of our "Regulatory Cornucopia" scenario on the Future of ESG that projected proliferation of metrics > Stakeholder Capitalism Metrics Initiative: over 120 companies implement the ESG reporting metrics https://t.co/tMSEMVgyJq via @wef

It was interesting to see JOFS feature this oldie but goodie on how to frame and discuss what futurists can deliver -- still relevant! Let’s Talk about Success: A Proposed Foresight Outcomes Framework for Organizational Futurists https://t.co/U7xs0A68Ok
I wonder how Fox News feels about being quoted by this site (ah, the irony)  > In Defense of Communism: Enjoying Capitalism? New York City's homeless reac... https://t.co/pRKd72XoLc

Homo Deus by Harari suggests that biology and robotics could lead the "upgrading" of humans into a new species, via genetic engineering or as cyborgs. Tech-Led Abundance could lead After Capitalism into some strange places. See https://t.co/kKYuFJ96QD

A good cherry-pick > "It’s also worth noting that US economic confidence is the highest it has been in nearly 20 years." Source is Jan 2020 - pandemic starts March 2020! from "The Anti-Capitalists Are (Still) Wrong about History" https://t.co/9PnQGBOpnS via @feeonline
A Dozen Tips for Thinking about the Future video. https://t.co/FGpatAxr0W
@KarlSchroeder That makes two of us! But I do plan to keep at this topic, so we will see.
This is [part of] what redistribution is addressing. beautiful graphic work here!

David Schweickart, a long-time advocate for After Capitalism offers Economic Democracy, a socialist approach centered on worker self-management, a market for enterprises, and social control of investment. I wouldn’t use socialist, but great concepts! https://t.co/Vi3iKD3T6x https://t.co/gesFaQI5eo
"Quiet quitting" is understandable — but it won't save us from predatory capitalism [true, but it's a start] https://t.co/yvaSVAjRhg
Amazing company and individual that continues to be ahead of the curve! Patagonia founder gives away company to help fight climate crisis https://t.co/IIMX03x0lD via @YahooFinance

"Leaving breadcrumbs to the future." Communicating insights about the future in small ways in different formats at different times. Thx  Sharaelle Grzesiak, Director of Strategic Foresight at GA0, for this beautiful metaphor!!! More> https://t.co/nuKRSEzQ89
Steve Jobs Said 1 Thing Separates Successful People From Everyone Else, basically "get started." Absolutely!_I've been calling it "in motion." Don't wait for the future! https://t.co/cPEqdv7ROp

The outrage about the pretty mild student loan forgiveness program gives us a pretty good indication of the depth of the struggle ahead on redistribution. The #1 challenge is the “fairness” argument. https://t.co/K8vAawPpvl

More common(s). De Angelis focuses on the political aspect of a commons with a highly local model of people self-organizing socially and politically within communities to govern resources together. Models are coming, but still small scale. See https://t.co/vQDJ88jTlJ https://t.co/neIcLmj1zw

Buckle up -- it's going to get "interesting." I don't agree with this approach -- gets into us vs them in which everybody loses. 
The Masked Vigilantes Coming for Your Horrible Boss https://t.co/Ly4uusYLav via @Pocket

I have mixed feelings on this. Good to be looking post-capitalist, but the Marxist framing is best avoided if we want to get After Capitalism into the mainstream. 
 
‘A new way of life’: the Marxist, post-capitalist, green manifesto captivating Japan https://t.co/pRR3NunlSV

Four scenarios of the After Capitalism future by Peter Frase are framed on uncertainties about abundance and inequality. Personally, I don’t like to use the historical framings of socialism and communism, but a very helpful snapshot. See https://t.co/rlCl9Vs2mQ https://t.co/67DzS2e4oW

Moving from private property towards a commons approach is a key shift in the Circular Commons image. Communities managing resources encourages political and social freedom. David Bollier suggests we can start can building pilots right now! See https://t.co/cF22VdP5VU https://t.co/7CFMyql2hX
Envisioning the Transition to an Ecological Economy https://t.co/N7cQsKdpKv This is an excellent piece on the challenges of moving to After Capitalism!
Let's not demonize capitalism on the journey to after capitalism. We are going to need to bring as many supporters of capitalism on board as we can.  https://t.co/1zfhOU6Pep https://t.co/2IEd5QRhMZ
The importance of Bronze Age Pervert @UnHerd https://t.co/G9pMI6Rx1i Very balanced and insightul analysis of a movement on the right worth understanding.

Abundance by Peter Diamandis says tech progress will be so great that within a generation, goods and services once reserved for the wealthy few will be available to all. This is core to the Tech-Led Abundance image and an enabler of the post-work future: https://t.co/o3ztuA8fkB

Alter-Worlds, a manifesto for a wage-less life, is excellent fit with the Non-Workers Paradise image of After Capitalism. A key contribution is that there are opportunities to act right now by leveraging movements springing up outside the system. See https://t.co/g7pL4rUhKG
To Fight Severe Drought, China Is Turning to Technology | https://t.co/Kl5yhBK2Qv via @ChuckSherwood1 https://t.co/VnNSUxQz6V   What could possibly go wrong??

The Circular Economy work of the MacArthur Foundation is essential to the Circular Commons image of After Capitalism. Basic idea: today’s goods are tomorrow’s resources: durable goods esigned for re-use; consumables are composted. See: https://t.co/Bw1aQjbMIK

Degrowth Gains Ground https://t.co/JzKKG08LJH 
Indeed It has moved from the fringe towards the mainstream. Not quite fully there, but was dismissed as crazy not too long ago.

The three guiding images for After Capitalism -- Circular Commons, Non-Workers Paradise, and Tech-Led Abundances -- each have their own story and appeal. Which speaks to you?  https://t.co/ARdxTF46x6 https://t.co/adb4BGQ5Gw

Spot-on > "Most Democrats don’t really see themselves as belonging to a political party, but rather as members of a social group. The game of hard nose politics is anathema to them, as they prefer to think of themselves as superior beings who can look down on the MAGA rabble."
Liz Cheney Positioning for Presidential Bid https://t.co/gQExOqGptP via @freedomrideblog

@foxweather @FOX26Houston @Fox26Mike The evidence suggests that kinds of freak weather events are going to be more common. But our current capitalist approach struggles to find a way to prepare for   them. We need a new approach: https://t.co/CZNnfNtEZS

@axios Reading through the "unfairness" comments brought to mind my trip to Finland this summer to visit a "competitor" graduate school to my Foresight program at U of Houston. How much is your tuition... I ask. It's free, they say! There is a different way of doing things!!!

In setting up foresight, champions typically have a vague idea of what they want, and futurists must help them understand what foresight can do!
https://t.co/qBatRY7aXB https://t.co/gsPoH3PP5p

@JohnStossel Young people are against capitalism, but that does not make them for socialism. We literally have no ideas for the future, so we fall back on socialism. We desperately need images of future after capitalism https://t.co/CZNnfNt7ak

It ain't a good sign when Mitch McConnell starts to look reasonable. Oof
Trump slams McConnell as ‘disloyal’ amid Jan. 6 hearings https://t.co/bybfk0Y8cM

"Betterness" by Umair Haque suggests the current negative business paradigm based on fixing errors should give way to a positive one focusing beyond the bottom line to considering real human welfare. [Fits w/ Circular Commons image] https://t.co/CZNnfNt7ak https://t.co/6nCJpHtlQe
Oops, key missing word was YOUTH are neither lazy nor socialists

@WSJ Warriors shifting to giggers? It seems more warriors (fiercely committed to their job and go above and beyond the call of duty) are becoming giggers (transactional approach to their gigs or jobs in which they will provide what they believe is reasonable and nothing more)
